Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Development of an Undergrad Bioinformatics and Biomathematics Track at Fisk University to Enhance Undergrad STEM Education, Research, and Future Careers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To enhance and expand undergraduate science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) interdisciplinary education and research, Fisk University is designing three new undergraduate courses ? Biomathematics I and II and Bioinformatics ? to offer its students over the next three years. The infusion of focused funding from the National Science Foundation's Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) for these new courses creates a new interface between existing STEM courses in mathematics, biology and computer science.
To meet the calculus need of biology students, the biomathematics courses focus on topics that have immediate relevance to understanding biological phenomena and introduce students to hands-on modeling of biological phenomena using relevant mathematical theory. Similarly, the bioinformatics course introduces students to hands-on computer science and information technologies essential for contemporary biology disciplines. Students will engage in faculty mentored summer research and professional development activities addressing unsolved research questions directly related to the topics covered in the three courses.
This project establishes a strong interdisciplinary research base at Fisk University and brings a new awareness for quantitative research in biological sciences. The activities are expected to increase student interest in STEM-related fields, attract and increase retention at the undergraduate level and student progression in STEM disciplines to graduate studies, and serve as a possible replicable model for other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit

 The intellectual merit of the project lies in the fact that this project established the first step in Fisk University towards expanding into future degree-granting biomathematics and bioinformatics programs. To meet the calculus need of biology students, the proposed Biomathematics I course focused on the topics of calculus I that have immediate relevance to understanding biological phenomena. Increasing the application relevance increased student interest and academic success in meeting the Calculus I requirement for Biology and Chemistry Majors. Mathematical Modeling of Biological Systems course introduced students to hands-on modeling of biological phenomena using relevant mathematical theory. The Bioinformatics course introduced students to hands-on computer science and information technologies essential for contemporary biology disciplines. Selected students engaged in summer research, mentored by program faculty mentors addressing unsolved research questions directly related to the topics covered in the three new courses. This combination of activities (1) provided a solid link between mathematics, computer science and their use in biology, (2) provided a strong foundation for subsequent quantitative development in biological courses, (3) fostered quantitative and discovery based learning on the topics of life sciences, (4) prepared students for technology oriented today’s job market, and (5) provided the departments (mathematics, computer science and biology) to offer a new emphasis area. The project also supported a significant level of professional developmental activities for mathematics, biology and computer science faculty. 

The broader impact:

Since the sequencing of the human genome and the rise of ‘systems biology’ as a discipline, biology has emerged as the most dominant natural science partner with mathematics and computer science in both research and education. This TIP project established a strong interdisciplinary research base at Fisk University and brought a new awareness for quantitative research in biological sciences. Fisk University, an HBCU, has > 98% students of color, and > 90% students being African-American, resulting in a direct impact on this population of increasing awareness and skills related to this rapidly expanding career opportunity. The activities increased students’ interest in STEM related fields, increased retention and progression in STEM disciplines, and served as a possible replicable model for other institutions that share a similar mission. In addition, for those students who were already aware of the impact of biomathematics and informatics on biological sciences, this new emphasis area at Fisk both increased recruitment of STEM trainees to Fisk as well as increased the number of Fisk students to attend graduate school in STEM related fields. 

In summary:

The principal goal of this project was to develop an undergraduate bioinformatics and biomathematics track at Fisk University in order to enhance the undergraduate STEM education, research and future careers of Fisk students. The strategy used to achieve this goal was through developing and implementing three undergraduate biomathematics courses, offering faculty-mentored summer research internship, organizing guest seminars on campus on biomathematics or bioinformatics topics and preparing students to present and publish their research work in national undergraduate conferences and in undergraduate journals respectively.

This project was transformative at Fisk, and had direct impact on 107 undergraduate students: 85 students through the newly developed Biomathematics I and II and Bioinformatics courses; 22 students through faculty mentored summer research programs. All of these students are minorities, 60% of the students were female. Twenty five students presented their research at national conferences. The acknowledged impact of this TIP project contributed significantly to the institutional vision to strategically focus in STEM on enhanced quantitative and computational skills among our trainees and on building research capacity in these critical areas. This project has established a strong foundation for quantitative applications of biological systems at Fisk University and has increased student’s interest and awareness of the importance of computational and quantitative skills in biology. Our summer research participants have pursued their research study in various different interdisciplinary topics involving mathematics, biology and computer science and have presented their work in ABRCMS, NCUR, ERN and NIMBioS Undergraduate Research Conferences during each of the project years. A number of scholars have received travel awards and their research projects were ranked within the top three positions.

This project has expanded our faculty collaborations and fostered development of new grant proposals led by other Fisk Faculty. Importantly, faculty-faculty collaborations at Fisk, with undergraduate mentees as research collaborators, has led to a much enriched interdisciplinary research culture.
